We know by instinct that humour is pretty
important in relationships. But the reasons

6.text:
are often left a little vague. It isn’t
that we crudely want entertainment – there

11.text:
are enough comedians on TV. We don’t just
want a laugh per se.

16.text: For two people to be able to tolerate one another over time we need to laugh.

21.text: In the nicest way at our partner and at ourselves.  Spending time closely around someone

28.text:
inevitably exposes us to constant departures from what
we can call normality or balance. Our partners

35.text: will be a little crazy in many areas and we will be too of course.  They might turn out

53.text:
We need to say something, but doing so directly
and in a serious voice can be painfully counter-productive.

59.text:
Too often, the partner just feels swiftly 
attacked and refuses the insight. Leading to stifled irritation and bitterness.  This is

69.text: where humour comes in.  Humour is the most effective way of criticising another person without

75.text:
arousing their irritation or self-righteousness.
Their laughter isn’t just fun it's a

80.text: sign that they have acknowledged an attempt to reform them.

84.text: If people tend to get annoyed when criticism is delivered in a serious tone, it's

91.text: It's that they can't see the extent to which their attitudes have abandoned proportion and balance.

95.text: They are unable to spot their deviation from the mature meme.

100.text: So the comedic gesture involves subjecting the troublesome aspect of the other

103.text: to extreme exaggeration – which then jolts them

107.text:
into recognition
of a problem, while at the same time offering them the

111.text:
relief  of feeling that they arn't, of course, quite
that bad.

In the late 1980s, the then British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher grew increasingly
authoritarian with her colleagues and fellow

123.text:
politicians. Serious-minded articles appeared
in newspapers urging the Prime Minister to

128.text:
be more collegiate and empathetic. It didn’t
work at all; Mrs Thatcher simply got offended

133.text:
and dug in. But then a comedy show using puppets
called Spitting Image turned the Prime Minister

139.text:
into a deep-voiced, psychopathic matron with
a tendency to whack her naughty colleagues

143.text:
over the head with a truncheon. This obviously
wasn’t how Mrs Thatcher actually behaved,

148.text:
and yet it was a tenfold exaggeration of a
real – and painful – truth about her.

154.text:
Remarkably, presented in this form, the Prime
Minister could see the point, felt assuaged

159.text:
by the wildness of the exaggeration and was
in a position to laugh at herself. In her

165.text:
memoirs, she recalled tuning into the programme
and chuckling – realising that she would

169.text:
henceforth need to learn to reign in a tendency
that had clearly gotten out of hand. The comedy

175.text:
show was rehearsing a move we all need constantly
to make in our relationships.

228.text:

233.text:

Comedy skilfully teaches us that the way to

240.text:
get someone to see that they have over-reacted
is not to sound mature and reasonable. It’s

245.text:
to continue to pump up the problem until the
over-reaction becomes so clear, so benign

251.text:
by its outsize dimensions that our audience
starts to laugh. We’ll have learnt to criticise

258.text:

be a whole lot more secure as a result, especially

264.text:
when we allow our lover to magnify our own
failings into jokes in turn.
